S6.T1.caption: Table 1: A summary of setups: the four setups cover different Federated Learning scenarios, non-IID types and task types.
S6.T1.table:
Setup # Clients Model Scenario Non-IID Type Task Type
Femnist 3500 MLP Cross Device Intrinsic Computer Vision
Cifar10 16 CNN Cross Silo Dirichlet Computer Vision
Sent140 697 LSTM Cross Device Intrinsic Natural Language Process
Synthetic 100 Linear Model Cross Device/Silo Synthetic Classification
references: To validates the effectiveness and robustness of AdaFedAdam, four federated setups are used: 1). Femnist setup: A multi-layer perceptron (MLP) network ([23]) for image classification on Federated EMNIST dataset ([3]), proposed by [1] as a benchmark task for federated learning; 2). Cifar10 setup: VGG11 ([27]) for image classification on Cifar10 dataset ([13]) partitioned by Dirichlet distribution Dirâ€‹(0.05)Dir0.05\textbf{Dir}(0.05) for 16 clients; 3). Sent140 setup: A stacked-LSTM model ([5]) for sentiment analysis on the Text Dataset of Tweets ([6]); 4). Synthetic setup: A linear regression classifier for multi-class classification on a synthetic dataset (Synthetic), proposed by [1] as a challenging task for benchmarking federated algorithms. A summary of four setups are shown in Table 1. Details of the model architectures and experimental settings are available in C.1.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Experimental results of federated algorithms against resource heterogeneity on the Cifar10 setup. Time-varying numbers of local epochs are sampled from a uniform distribution ğ’°â€‹(1,3)ğ’°13\mathcal{U}(1,3) in each communication round.
S6.T2.table:
Algorithm Avg.(%) STD.(%) Worst 30. (%)
FedAvg 36.82 Â±1.45 21.32 Â±1.89 10.69 Â±3.29
FedAdam 54.57 Â±1.87 13.03 Â±2.53 40.32 Â±5.11
q-FedAvg 27.36 Â±1.09 24.34 Â±1.35 2.67 Â±1.16
FedNova 38.03 Â±1.18 24.99 Â±2.15 6.24 Â±2.96
AdaFedAdam 63.26 Â±1.41 8.64 Â±1.35 45.07 Â±2.38
references: Robustness against resource heterogeneity is important for algorithms to be applied in real life. Due to the heterogeneity of clientsâ€™ computing resources, the server cannot expect all participants perform requested number of local steps / epochs in each global round and thus, clients may perform arbitrary numbers of local steps on the global model in each communication round. To simulate settings of resource heterogeneity, time-varying numbers of local epochs are randomly sampled from a uniform distribution ğ’°â€‹(1,3)ğ’°13\mathcal{U}(1,3) in each communication round for each participant. The results are shonw in Table 2. With resource heterogeneity, AdaFedAdam outperform other federated algorithms with higher average accuracy and more fairness.

S6.T3.caption: Table 3: Experimental results of AdaFedAdam in different levels of non-iid settings on the Cifar10 setup.
S6.T3.table:
Distribution Avg.(%) STD.(%) Worst 30. (%)
Dirâ€‹(0.05)Dir0.05\textbf{Dir}(0.05) 62.81 Â±1.02 8.18 Â±1.33 46.01 Â±2.23
Dirâ€‹(0.1)Dir0.1\textbf{Dir}(0.1) 66.16 Â±1.13 6.58 Â±0.77 55.26 Â±2.83
Dirâ€‹(0.5)Dir0.5\textbf{Dir}(0.5) 71.43 Â±0.81 5.4 Â±0.22 64.93 Â±1.04

references: Robustness against different non-IID levels ensures the performance of an algorithm in various application cases. To simulate different non-IID levels, the Cifar10 dataset is partitioned by the Dirichlet distribution over labels with different concentration parameters Î²âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›½01\beta\in[0,1], denoted as Dirâ€‹(Î²)Dirğ›½\textbf{Dir}(\beta). A smaller value of Î²ğ›½\beta indicates larger level of data heterogeneity. The results are shown in Table 3. With different levels of data heterogeneity, AdaFedAdam is able to converge, and better performance and fairness are obtained in settings with less data heterogeneity, as expected.

Different levels of data heterogeneity are generated with Dirichlet distribution of different concentration parameter Î²ğ›½\beta ranging from 0.050.050.05 to 0.50.50.5 and together with an IID partitioning. It can be observed that AdaFedAdam consistently outperforms other algorithms with the highest test accuracy and lowest STD of test accuracy in all different settings.
